docs.lead_paragraph: Gabriella Irizarry was better prepared for her own death than most people who face the trials of old age or illness. Heartbreakingly so. When she died, Gabby was 5 1/2 years old. Her ordeal began in 1992, when her mother, Francisca Rodriguez, a writer and community coordinator at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, learned that her former husband had collapsed and died of AIDS. Ms. Rodriguez, it turned out, was also infected and had passed the virus to Gabby at birth.

headline.main: Gift for a Dying Daughter: Orders to Spare Her Pain

docs.abstract: Second of two articles, Talking Around Death, focuses on late Francisca Rodriguez and her 5 1/2-year-old daughter Gabriella; Francisca learned in 1992 that her former husband had infected her with AIDS virus and that she had passed virus to Gabriella at birth; Rodriguez was determined to take charge of her care from moment she learned she was ill; she was equally emphatic about what she wanted for her baby--no experimental drugs and no machines that would give her heartbeat without giving her life; Rodriguez died at home on July 8, 1993; Gabriella followed her mother in death two years and four months later, one of 20 people who died at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan during first 11 days of Nov 1995; examination of records of patients who died at Beth Israel during this period suggests that public debate over issues surrounding dying process has not trickled down to discussions between patients and their families, and patients and their doctors; photos (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The word on the streets and in the crack houses of the inner city is that the new AIDS medicines can stop the virus that causes the disease from progressing. But not everyone can get the new drugs: Doctors are withholding them from ''unreliable'' patients. This poses an ethical problem, exposing the immense gulf between expanding scientific knowledge and the wisdom needed to deal with the epidemic humanely. The policy may also have dangerous consequences, affecting our ability to control AIDS in the future. The doctors choosing who will or will not get the latest medication appear to be making their decisions based on scientific fact. Because H.I.V. multiplies and mutates rapidly, they reason, the virus will become drug-resistant in people who take their medicine sporadically. And if drug-resistant strains spread, ultimately making the medicines ineffective, that would create an even more serious public health problem.
docs.abstract: Daniel Baxter Op-Ed article contends that doctors are withholding new AIDS medications from 'unreliable' patients that can stop disease from progressing; maintains that withholding new forms of treatment from chronically homeless and substance abusers may accelerate spread of drug-resistant HIV (M)
docs.snippet: The word on the streets and in the crack houses of the inner city is that the new AIDS medicines can stop the virus that causes the disease from progressing. But not everyone can get the new drugs: Doctors are withholding them from ''unreliable''...

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty people died at Beth Israel Medical Center from Nov. 1 to Nov. 11, 1995. Each death was a personal loss, but together the cases offer a glimpse of the complicated decisions that arise when death nears and the aversion people have to talking about such matters in advance. Martin Isaacs was typical of many people who died in this period: he was older, he had been sick for some time he had never spoken to his family or doctor about ''end of life'' care. Some families and doctors of those who had died were willing to talk but not to be identified. In other cases only the hospital records were available. Some deaths were swift, others slow. Some involved difficult decisions; others offered almost no choices to families or doctors and nurses. They are presented in the order they occurred. Nov. 1, 4:20 P.M. A Joint Decision At 4:20 P.M., a 42-year-old man with AIDS died after a severe case of pneumonia. He had been in the hospital for two and a half months, since Aug. 17, when his companion brought him in, weak and fatigued.

headline.main: Chronicling the End for 20: Hard Choices Are Harder When Wishes Go Unsaid

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced a new system today for regulating medical products made from human tissues that the agency says addresses safety issues while reducing barriers to new therapies. The agency said its new framework for overseeing human tissue products ranging from corneal transplants to cells used for gene therapy would allow for more consistent regulation based on the degree of risk to patients being treated.

headline.main: Rules to Cover Human Tissue In Products
